question.name: 7.2.6.5 Communication network example
question.questiontext:
Example

Communication network

Problem in words

The figure below represents a communication network. Vertices \(a, b, f\) and \(g\) represent offices. Vertices \(c, d\) and \(e\) represent switching centres. The numbers marked along the edges represent the number of connections between any two vertices. Calculate the number of routes from \(a\) and \(b\) to \(f\) and \(g.\)

Mathematical statement of the problem

The number of routes from \(a\) to \(f\) can be calculated by taking the number via \(c\) plus the number via \(d\) plus the number via \(e\). In each case this is given by multiplying the number of connections along the edges connecting \(a\) to \(c\), \(c\) to \(f\) etc. This gives the result: \[\text{Number of routes from }a\text{ to }f = 3\times2 + 4\times 6 + 1\times 1=31.\] The nature of matrix multiplication means that the number of routes is obtained by multiplying the matrix representing the number of connections from \(ab\) to \(cde\) by the matrix representing the number of connections from \(cde\) to \(fg\).

Mathematical analysis

The matrix representing the number of routes from \(ab\) to \(cde\) is: \[ \begin{matrix} & \begin{matrix} c & d & e \end{matrix}\\ \begin{matrix} a \\ b\end{matrix}\!\!\!\!\! & \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\end{matrix}\] The matrix representing the number of routes from \(cde\) to \(fg\) is: \[\begin{matrix} & \begin{matrix} f & g \end{matrix} \\ \begin{matrix} c \\ d \\ e \end{matrix}\!\!\!\!\! & \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 6 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \end{matrix}\] The product of these two matrices gives the total number of routes: \begin{align*} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 6 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} & = \begin{bmatrix} 3\times 2+4\times 6+1\times1 & 3\times 1+4\times 3+1\times 2 \\ 2\times2+1\times 6+3\times 1 & 2\times 1+1\times 3+3\times 2 \end{bmatrix} \\ & = \begin{bmatrix} 31 & 17 \\ 13 & 11 \end{bmatrix} \end{align*}

Interpretation
We can interpret the resulting (product) matrix by labelling the columns and rows: \[\begin{matrix} & \begin{matrix} f & g \end{matrix} \\ \begin{matrix} a \\ b \end{matrix}\!\!\!\!\! & \begin{bmatrix} 31 & 17 \\ 13 & 11 \end{bmatrix} \end{matrix}\] Hence there are \(31\) routes from \(a\) to \(f\), \(17\) from \(a\) to \(g\), \(13\) from \(b\) to \(f\) and \(11\) from \(b\) to \(g\).
